perturbation.changed_text:
6.19. Insurance.
6.19.1. Types and Amounts of Coverage. Throughout the entire Term, you must maintain such types of insurance, in such amounts, as we may require. Such insurance is in addition to any other insurance that may be required by applicable law, your landlord, or otherwise. Policies that we require must be written by an insurance company reasonably satisfactory to us with an A.M. Best rating of "A" or better, and, must name us as an additional insured party.  At any time, we may adjust the amounts of coverage required under such insurance policies and require different or additional kinds of insurance, including excess liability insurance.
6.19.2. Evidence of Insurance. By the dates specified below, an approved insurance company must issue a certificate of insurance showing compliance with the insurance requirements in this Section 6.19 [Insurance] and you must furnish us with a paid receipt showing the certificate number: (a) 30 days before beginning construction of the Premises; (b) if the Premises are constructed and presently owned or leased by you, 10 days from the Agreement Date; or (c) if the Premises are not presently owned or leased, 10 days after ownership of the Premises is conveyed to you or you sign a lease for the Premises.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the minimum insurance coverage requirements (e.g., commercial general liability of $1,000,000 per person/per occurrence, workers' compensation, fire insurance, automobile liability, commercial blanket bond), the contract no longer guarantees a minimum level of protection, which could be a legal requirement in Florida for businesses operating in the food service industry. Specifically, the removal of the sentence stating, 'The certificate of insurance must include a statement by the insurer that the policy or policies may not be canceled, subject to nonrenewal, or materially altered without at least 30 days' prior written notice to us' opens the franchisee to great risk. Additionally, this violates general business law by failing to meet minimum standards of insurance coverage.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida Statutes regarding minimum insurance requirements for businesses and general business law.

perturbation.original_text: 15.2.15. You cease to operate the Franchised Business for more than seven (7) consecutive days or fourteen (14) days in any calendar year unless we approved a temporary closing or we determine, that the failure to operate was beyond your control, you otherwise abandon the Franchised Business, or you lose the right to possess the Premises or you otherwise forfeit the right to do or transact business as required under this Agreement. If, however, through no fault of you, the Premises are damaged or destroyed by an event such that repairs or reconstruction cannot be completed within ninety (90) days thereafter, you will have thirty (30) days after such event in which to apply for our approval to relocate and/or reconstruct the premises, and we will not unreasonably hold our approval.
perturbation.changed_text: 15.2.15. You cease to operate the Franchised Business for more than seven (7) consecutive days or fourteen (14) days in any calendar year unless we approved a temporary closing or we determine, that the failure to operate was beyond your control, you otherwise abandon the Franchised Business, or you lose the right to possess the Premises or you otherwise forfeit the right to do or transact business as required under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the clause addressing premises damage or destruction, the franchisee loses the legally mandated right to seek relocation or reconstruction approval in cases of unforeseen events. This omission contradicts potential Florida law which stipulates businesses should have reasonable options for continuation or relocation following significant, unavoidable damages.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida laws pertaining to business operation rights and force majeure.

perturbation.original_text: 25.5. Mutual Waiver of Punitive Damages. Each of us waives any right to or claim of punitive, exemplary, multiple, or consequential damages against the other in litigation and agrees to be limited to the recovery of actual damages sustained.
perturbation.changed_text: 25.5. Mutual Waiver of Punitive Damages. Each of us waives any right to or claim of punitive, exemplary, multiple, or consequential damages against the other in litigation.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'and agrees to be limited to the recovery of actual damages sustained', the clause now waives punitive damages but fails to explicitly limit the recovery to actual damages. This creates ambiguity. While a waiver of punitive damages can be permissible, it's often scrutinized, especially if it leaves room for unlimited other types of damages like consequential damages which can disproportionately harm a franchisee. Florida law has provisions around what is permissible in contractual waivers, particularly concerning franchise agreements to ensure fairness and good faith. This modification creates a potential legal risk by being vaguely worded and potentially overly broad.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida Statutes regarding contract law, specifically relating to waivers and limitations of liability in franchise agreements and the interpretation of ambiguous clauses.
